statement.tex: Find the minimum (or maximum) value of \[ \qquad \qquad f(x) = x\cdot e^x \]

options.tex: %text $f'(x) = \dfx$. And therefore, $f(x)$ has an extrema at $x = -1$ \incorrect $f'(x) = \dfx$. And therefore, $f(x)$ has an extrema at $x = 0,-1$%
%text $f'(x) = \dfx$. And therefore, $f(x)$ has an extrema at $x = 0,-1$%

reason.tex:
%text We know that $f'(x) = 0$ at $x=-1$. To know, however, whether it is a maxima or a minima, one must look at $f''(x)$ % \begin{align}
f''(x) &= \ddx f'(x) = \ddx \dfx \\ &= (x+1)\ddx e^x + e^x\ddx (x+1) \\ &= (x+1) \cdot e^x + e^x = \ddfx \\ f''(-1) &= e^{-1} = \frac{1}{e} > 0 \end{align} %text As $f''(x) > 0$ at $x=-1$, therefore we have a minima at $x=-1$. And the minimum value is \[ \qquad f_{min} = f(-1) = -1\cdot e^{-1} = -\frac{1}{e}\] %
